prior_works.title: Representing Scenes as Neural Radiance Fields for View Synthesis
prior_works.authors: Ben Mildenhall, Pratul P. Srinivasan, Matthew Tancik, Jonathan T. Barron, Ravi Ramamoorthi, Ren Ng
prior_works.relationship_sentence: AVR directly generalizes NeRF’s volumetric transmittance-integral and neural field parameterization from radiance to acoustics, replacing scalar RGB emission with complex, frequency-dependent acoustic propagation (attenuation and phase) along rays.

prior_works.title: The Rendering Equation
prior_works.role: Core integral formulation and spherical-direction integration
prior_works.relationship_sentence: AVR mirrors the rendering equation’s integration over directions by performing spherical integration of incoming acoustic contributions, adapting the light transport formalism to sound propagation and IR fitting.

prior_works.title: Optical Models for Direct Volume Rendering
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s frequency-domain volume rendering inherits Max’s absorption–emission with cumulative transmittance along a path, which AVR reinterprets as complex-valued acoustic attenuation and phase accumulation through a participating ‘acoustic’ medium.

prior_works.title: Image Method for Efficiently Simulating Small-Room Acoustics
prior_works.authors: Jont B. Allen, David A. Berkley
prior_works.role: Classical physical model for room impulse responses
prior_works.relationship_sentence: AVR’s impulse response field targets the same multipath phenomena captured by the image-source method but learns a continuous field that implicitly encodes reflections and path lengths, aligning with and extending this physical intuition in a data-driven way.

prior_works.title: Implicit Neural Representations with Periodic Activation Functions (SIREN)
prior_works.authors: Vincent Sitzmann, Julien N. P. Martel, Alexander W. Bergman, David B. Lindell, Gordon Wetzstein
prior_works.role: Neural representation for high-frequency, wave-like signals
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Modeling frequency-domain IRs requires representing rapidly varying phase; SIREN-style periodic activations motivate AVR’s choice of neural field architectures capable of capturing high-frequency oscillatory structure.

prior_works.title: Fourier Features Let Networks Learn High Frequency Functions in Low Dimensional Domains
prior_works.authors: Matthew Tancik, Pratul P. Srinivasan, Ben Mildenhall, Sara Fridovich-Keil, Nithin Raghavan, Utkarsh Singhal, Ravi Ramamoorthi, Jonathan T. Barron, Ren Ng
prior_works.role: Positional encoding to represent high-frequency content
prior_works.relationship_sentence: AVR’s frequency-domain formulation benefits from Fourier-style encodings that stabilize learning of high-frequency phase and fine spatial variation in impulse response fields.

prior_works.title: Analysis and Design of Spherical Microphone Arrays
prior_works.role: Spherical integration and harmonic decomposition of sound fields
prior_works.relationship_sentence: AVR’s spherical integration over incoming directions is informed by spherical array/ambisonics literature, grounding its directional aggregation of acoustic energy and phase in established spherical harmonic analysis of sound fields.

synthesis_narrative:
Acoustic Volume Rendering (AVR) adapts the integral machinery of neural volumetric rendering to the acoustic domain of impulse responses. The key conceptual backbone comes from NeRF and classic volume rendering: the transmittance-weighted line integral (Max, NeRF) and directional integration (Kajiya) provide the calculus that AVR recasts into the frequency domain with complex-valued attenuation and phase accumulation, matching the physics of wave propagation. Allen and Berkley’s image method supplies the physical target—room impulse responses produced by multipath reflections and path-length-dependent delays—while motivating AVR’s goal: a continuous neural field that implicitly encodes these propagation effects and synthesizes IRs at arbitrary listener positions.
To make this feasible, AVR leans on advances in neural signal representations that handle high-frequency structure. SIREN motivates architectures capable of representing oscillatory, phase-sensitive fields, and Fourier feature encodings (as popularized in NeRF) stabilize learning of fine spatial and spectral detail required by frequency-domain IRs. Finally, the paper’s spherical integration step is anchored in the ambisonics and spherical microphone array literature (Rafaely), which formalizes aggregation of incoming directional sound components over the sphere. Together, these works converge into AVR’s core innovation: a frequency-domain neural volume rendering formulation with spherical integration that learns an impulse response field encoding acoustic wave propagation, enabling state-of-the-art IR synthesis across positions.
